title: Celebration of North East skills as various schemes tackle industry shortfalls
text:
Celebration of North East skills as various schemes tackle industry shortfalls 13:00, 7 Oct 2016 By Jez Davison With the skills debate high on the business agenda, a series of innovative schemes are showcasing North East talent Share Comments Get business news by email Simon Park (far left), energy and environment adviser at Esh Group, and Rita Callender (second left), business improvement manager at Esh, with apprentices at the company 
The UK construction industry is rarely lauded for its green credentials but one sustainability scheme is aiming to cut carbon emissions on building projects while training the next generation of industry talent. 
Run by Bowburn-based Esh Group and funded by the Construction Industry Training Board (CITB), the initiative is teaching 50 apprentices about the value of energy management, carbon footprint monitoring and energy efficiency technologies. 
It aims to give young recruits starting out in construction the awareness and know-how to shape a sustainable future for the industry, while at the same time saving money for their employer. 
The apprentices will complete the four-module course online before applying their learning to real-life construction site situations. The idea is that this knowledge will allow them – and the construction firms that employ them – to become more savvy about slashing carbon consumption on property developments and other building projects. 
Esh Group said the scheme would help to drive up industry standards and fast-track of pipeline of new talent into the sector. 
Rita Callender, business improvement manager at Esh, said: “The idea is to capture these young people early and train them so that they have the skills they need to be successful in the industry. They can then influence other people and become a champion of best practice. We want them to pass on what they’ve learned to others as that’s the best way of improving the industry and making it more competitive. 
“The course is about two key things: tackling a skills shortage in the construction industry and meeting carbon reduction targets. As far as I’m aware there’s nothing like this in the industry.” Northumbria University and Parker domnic hunter representatives work on the knowledge transfer partnership. From l-r: Ellie Jones strategic marketing KTP associate; Callum Whitehead, industrial design KTP Associate; Craig Annal, principal engineer and company supervisor; Chris Mayes, market development manager (food & beverage) and company supervisor; Matthew Lievesley; Northumbria University academic lead; Neil McPherson, marketing manager and company lead; Nigel Coates, strategic marketing academic supervisor; Fraser McLeay; strategic marketing academic lead. 
It has certainly received the thumbs-up from the CITB, which ploughed £34,600 into the project. The organisation said it was impressed by Esh Group’s ambitions for its workforce and its commitment to sustainability. 
Geeta Nathan, head of economic analysis at CITB, said: “We are proud to fund a project committed to providing apprentices with the skills and training that will benefit the industry and the environment. 
“The course will have a positive impact in the region and provide the next generation of construction workers with high-quality, innovative training to give them the best start to their careers.” 
Esh has a strong track record of championing workforce development. The £300m turnover company employs around 1,200 staff, of which 150 are apprentices – more than 10% of its workforce. 
Esh also makes an effort to engage with education providers to get young people interested in construction. 
It has teamed up with more than 70 primary schools to deliver its STEM (science, technology, engineering and mathematics) programme, which gives children a fun insight into the industry. The firm also works with secondary schools and colleges through its award-winning Building My Skills project, which was created in partnership with construction firms Arup, Ryder and Turner Townsend. 
Ms Callender said: “It’s vital that we inspire more people to come into our industry. I’ve found that our apprentices bring new blood into the business and give a fresh insight. Some companies might think they’re a draw on resources but I think they’re hugely important. They’re keen, sharp, dedicated and a valuable resource for us.” 
Esh is now seeking to persuade at least 10 companies in its supply chain to adopt its sustainability programme, a move that will allow more people to acquire vital skills in this field. Effective partnership working is a theme that runs through many other successful skills initiatives in the North East. 
Northumbria University specialises in Knowledge Transfer Partnerships (KTPs), where academics are drafted into businesses to help them solve a particular problem or make a strategic step-change in the way they operate. The idea is to give businesses the tools and knowledge to improve competitiveness, productivity and performance. Meanwhile, students are given valuable work experience in a company while completing their studies and the university benefits by acquiring knowledge that can shape future research. Fraser McLeay, professor of strategic marketing management at Northumbria University’s Newcastle Business School 
Northumbria has been involved in several KTPs, including one with engineering firm Parker domnick hunter. The university’s School of Design and Newcastle Business School worked with the Gateshead-based company, which makes compressed air and gas treatment technologies, on a two-year KTP designed to unearth new ways of developing, branding and selling these products. 
Ellie Jones, a strategic marketing associate from the business school, and industrial designer Callum Whitehead from the design school, helped Parker to find new applications for its products and make operational efficiencies that would reduce the time taken to bring a product to market. 
Parker said the KTP had the potential to “add several million pounds to our sales”. 
Neil McPherson, division marketing manager at the company, said: “About three years ago we undertook a review of our core strengths within the business. We found that we didn’t have an industrial design capability and didn’t really have a strategic marketing function either. As a result of the KPI our sales and engineering departments are more aligned with each other and we’ve identified two new market development opportunities that we’ve been able to progress.” 
He said the KTP had brought “out-of-the-box thinking into our business” and encouraged Parker to give a design makeover to some products that had carried the same appearance for 40 years. 
“If you went to a Ford garage you wouldn’t expect to buy a car that was made 40 years ago,” he said. “The KTP has helped us to re-energise activities in certain areas and encouraged us to bring younger people into the business, such as apprentices.” 
The project also showcased the problem-solving skills, effective teamwork and business acumen of the two Northumbria students – with demonstrable results. Read More Construction firm Galliford Try brushes off Brexit with contracts worth £60m 
Ellie said: “Our brief was to help Parker become more market-driven, or customer-centric, so that their engineering strengths are better aligned to what customers actually want. Because I work closely with Callum in a cross-faculty approach, we can show that the most cost-effective and profitable way of taking new products to market is when design and marketing complement each other by working together. By increasing flexibility in the process we’ve also shown that the time taken from concept to development stage can be significantly reduced from around 6-12 months to just 6-12 weeks. The positive impact of this can be huge.” 
The project also brought healthy benefits to Northumbria, which was recognised for its sterling KTP work in the most recent Times Higher Education Awards in which it was named UK Business School of the Year. The university has also worked on KTPs with Renown Engineering, which increased sales by £4m as a result of the project, and chemical manufacturing giant Thomas Swan. 
Fraser McLeay, professor of strategic marketing management at Newcastle Business School, said: “KTPs are a great way for businesses and universities to work together and share knowledge. From a university perspective it’s great to have academics working in businesses such as Parker domnick hunter. It allows us to bring knowledge back into the university and helps the development of the graduates. 
“All universities in the North East are involved in KTPs in some capacity but I don’t think that a lot of businesses realise the true value of them. Each business has the potential to make an extra £1m if they get involved in a KTP.” Seaward learners are in a different class Seaward’s successful manufacturing staff with their training certificates. Front (L-R): Ivy Hardwick, Lisa Egan, May Foster, Wendy Henderson, Louise Pratt. Back (L-R): Adam Cooke, Simon Davison, Robert Iley, Ian West 
Staff at a County Durham electronics manufacturer are celebrating after being recognised and rewarded for their achievements at a special awards ceremony. 
Peterlee-based Seaward awarded certificates to 10 production line assembly staff who have successfully gained a range of training qualifications including intermediate apprenticeships, business improvement techniques and manufacturing processes. 
The workers are the latest to complete the company’s in-house training programme, which combines on-the-job learning and more formal classroom sessions that are specifically geared towards helping staff improve their manufacturing skills and general education. 
Working with SEMTA, the Science, Engineering, Manufacturing and Technologies Alliance, and local training provider KF Training, the workers have now achieved nationally recognised qualifications that will help them in their day-to-day roles as well as with future career opportunities. 
Ian West, operations director at Seaward, said: “We recognise that our people are our biggest asset and we’re delighted to recognise the efforts and success of those who are committed to improving their education and knowledge. 
“We’re constantly striving to do things better and our training programmes are tailored around each individual to meet their specific needs and ambitions. Demand for talented and qualified people has never been greater and we’re happy to invest in our people to ensure that they reach their maximum potential.” 
Seaward has been established in Peterlee since 1982 and employs around 160 people. The company makes specialist test instruments for a range of industrial, engineering and medical sectors, supplying customers around the world. 
With an extensive distribution network in the UK, Seaward is represented worldwide across 30 countries and is committed to training and developing its workforce. Its training academy offers a variety of training courses designed to help workers develop their skills and knowledge and progress their career in PAT (portable appliance testing) and electrical installation.
